column4: A Muslim dynasty of caliphs (750 AD-1258 AD) with Baghdad as its capital for most of its history.
Term referring to a government with unlimited power vested in one individual or group.

The adda is an intellectual gathering among members of the Bengali intelligentsia. It started off as a leisurely activity in locations such as coffee houses, and was most popular among young middle class Bengali intellectuals. The concept of the adda has its roots in the city of Calcutta especially during the early 20th century. In modern times the concept has become more fluid.
The official publication of the American Historical Association.
Series of political events in the late 18th century in which the thirteen British colonies in North America revolted against the British Empire leading to their indepedence.

The Annales school is a school of history that is based on the French-language scholarly journal "Annales d'histoire économique et sociale".  Its main focus is on the pre-modern world, i.e. the period before the French Revolution. It deals mainly with social themes and an overall macro historical analysis of societies over a long period of time.  It has been the main source of influence in French history as well as European history.
A semitic language spoken by some 150 million people throughout the Middle East and North Africa.
An organized military force equipped for fighting on land.

On December 6th, 1992, a mob of Hindu militants demolished the Babri Masjid (Mosque of Babur) in the historic Indian town of Ayodhya and attacked other Muslim targets in the north. Hindu extremists believe that a Hindu temple should have been built in its place since it is the birthplace of an important Hindu god, Lord Rama. This event lead to the worst inter-community conflict since the partition in 1947.
An Indian political party representing Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and Other Backward Castes.
Battle in which the British East India Company defeated the Nawab of Bengal in 1757.
One of the first battles between Mysore and the British East India Company in the Second Anglo-Mysore War.

This term refers to a cultural movement and a period of social reform. It took place in the region of Bengal during the British Raj in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Bengal during this period was teeming with religious reformers, social reformers, scholars, intellectuals, scientists, literary geniuses, journalists, patriotic orators and freedom fighters. All of these individuals made unique intellectual and creative contributions to this movement.
The Indic language of Bangladesh and West Bengal.
Bengali term for the class of wealthy and educated "gentefolk" that arose during colonial Bengal.
The people of a nation, state, or society considered collectively as an organized group of citizens.
A member of the highest Hindu caste, that of the priesthood.
A former empire consisting of Great Britain and its possessions, dominions, and dependencies

Term referring to the Freedom of Intellect Movement which was started by the Bengali Muslim intelligentsia in the 1920s and 1930s. It was a rational humanist movement whereby intellectuals who still defined themselves as Muslims critiqued Islam and called for a subordination of its tenets to the principles of socio-economic well-being, individual freedom, and creativity.

The Calcutta Riots also known as the Great Calcutta Killings were the most deadly event in the history of the city.  The riots were a prolonged massacre between 1946 and 1947 resulting in thousands of deaths.
A monotheistic religion based on the life and teachings of Jesus of Nazareth.
A person who adheres to Christianity, an Abrahamic, monotheistic religion based on the life and teachings of Jesus of Nazareth.
A human subject or agent with legally prescribed rights and responsibilities. Citizenship status is granted by states and nations, it is a political privilege rather than a right.
A nonviolent movement in India led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi in 1930 to resist British rule.
A rationale for colonization where colonization is held to spread 'civilization' among non-Western peoples.

The Cold War, often dated from 1947 to 1991, was a sustained state of political and military tension between powers in the Western Bloc, dominated by the United States with NATO among its allies, and powers in the Eastern Bloc, dominated by the Soviet Union along with the Warsaw Pact.
The political control of one country by another.

The Commonwealth is considered to be a successor of the British Empire. It started to form when many of the colonies began to gain independence. The formal organization of the Commonwealth was developed from the Imperial Conferences where the independence of certain colonies was established.

Communism is considered to be a branch of socialism. It is a social movement and a policy party, and is associated with nation-states such as the USSR, China and Vietnam. Communism envisions a utopia in which classes are abolished and property is controlled. In its statements, it professes to provide an alternative to the problems of capitalism, imperialism and nationalism.

The CPI(M) was formed at the Seventh Congress of the Communist Party of India held in Calcutta from October 31 to November 7, 1964. The CPI(M) was born in the struggle against revisionism and sectarianism in the communist movement at the international and national level, in order to defend the scientific and revolutionary tenets of Marxism-Leninism and its appropriate application in the concrete Indian conditions.

The Cripps mission was an attempt by the British government to gain the cooperation and support of India for their efforts in World War II. The leader of this mission was Sir Stafford Cripps, a senior left-wing politician and government minister in the War Cabinet of Prime Minister Winston Churchill.
The name referring to the "untouchable" caste in Hindu society.
Plan by the Indian government to settle refugees from East Pakistan
A doctrine that holds decision making in a political field structured by the binary of friend and foe to be the main feature of politics
Deconstruction is a literary theory, introduced by French philosopher Jacques Derrida, that emphasizes the multiplicity of meanings and interpretations for any given text.
A post-graduate research center housed in the University of Delhi.

The Dutch East India Company was established in 1602. It was originally constituted as a chartered company, when the States-General of the Netherlands granted it a 21 year monopoly to carry out colonial activities in Asia. It was one of the first megacorporations  that had the power to issue stock and possessed several important government powers.
A broad term used to describe Europe between the fifteenth and eighteenth centuries

Chartered companies formed in the 17th century by various European states (England, the Netherlands, Denmark, Portugal, France etc). The companies held a monopoly in trade between their respective countries and Asia.
The ability of an individual to improve his or her economic status
The resources of a country or region, particular in terms of the production and consumption of good and services.
Focusing on European culture or history to the exclusion of a wider view of the world, implicitly regarding European culture as pre-eminent.
The war between the Sultanate of Mysore and the British East India Company from 1767 to 1769.
Arabic word denoting unrest or rebellion, especially against a rightful ruler
Roman goddess of fortune
Trade without restrictions on imports and exports

Gandhian Politics is the term given to the political methods and the political resources that Mahatma Gandhi employed to free India from colonial rule.  The two most famous of Gandhi's politics are satyagraha (The Path of Truth) and ahimsa or (Non-violence).

The study of the physical features of the earth and its atmosphere, and of human activity as it interacts with these, including the distribution of populations and resources and political and economic activities.

The processes that increase world-wide exchanges of national and cultural resources. Advances in transportation and telecommunications infrastructure, including the rise of the telegraph and its posterity the Internet, are major factors in globalization, generating further interdependence of economic and cultural activities.

The Gujrat Riots were the result of the burning of the Sabarmati Express train at Godhra city in the state of Gujarat. This took place on February 27, 2002 when the train was forcibly attacked by a large Muslim mob. This resulted in the death of many Hindu passengers who were returning from the holy city of Ayodhya.
People from the Hadhramaut region of Yemen
The Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca that all Muslims are expected to make at least once during their lifetime.
Word referring to a physician who uses traditional homeopathic remedies in India
A Hindu nationalist political party
Orginally from the French "histoires des mentalités," this term refers to the methods of historiography

A historical research journal established in 1976.  The journal publishes a wide variety of essays, reports and reviews, ranging from literary to economic subjects, local history to geopolitical analyses.
The empire set up in western Europe following the coronation of Charlemagne as emperor in 800 AD.

The Hungarian Revolution took place between October 23 and November 10, 1956 when a student lead demonstration marched through central Budapest to the Parliament Building. This revolt was a protest against the Soviet imposed policies of the People's Republic of Hungary. Many organized themselves into militias fighting the State Security Police and the Soviet troops.
The dynasty that ruled in Bengal from 1494 to 1538.

Political positions and activism based on an aspect of identity (e.g. ethnicity , religion, gender, or sexual orientation) shared by a group which feels that its concerns are not adequately represented.
The dynasty that ruled in Bengal from 1342 to 1487
Policy of extending a country's power via political, economic, or military force

The Indian National Congress (INC) is one of the most prominent political parties in India. This party was founded in 1885 by some of the leading political figures of the time. The INC played a major role in the Indian Independence Movement against British Rule. During the freedom movement the INC had 15 million members and over 70 million participants nation wide. Moreover, even after independence in 1947, it remained the main political party in Indian politics, lead by the Nehru-Gandhi family.

Interventionism is a term for a policy of non-defensive (proactive) activity undertaken by a nation-state, or other geo-political jurisdiction of a lesser or greater nature, to manipulate an economy or society. The most common applications of the term are for economic interventionism (a state's intervention in its own economy), and foreign interventionism (a state's intervention in the affairs of another nation as part of its foreign policy).
A monotheistic religion revealed by the prophet Muhammad beginning in the 7th century.  Its primary religious text is the Quran.
An Islamic concept that denotes religious or spiritual struggle
Hindu goddess associated with power
Hindu festival dedicated to the goddess Kali
Kashmir was ruled by independent sultans from 1320 to 1586, after which it was taken by the Mughals.
A Hindu caste whose members were traditionally employed as scribes
A region ruled by a khan (a Mongol or Turkic supreme tribal leader)
A kingdom ruled by the Nawabs of Awadh which became independent from Mughal rule in the eighteenth but soon thereafter came under British rule
A Bhumihar Brahmin state that was under Mughal and then British tutelage before joining the Indian Union.
Rulers of the Siak sultanate (1723-1946), which is today part of Indonesia

"Leftist Rule" refers to the rule or the political power of the Left—those who support social change to create a more equal society.  West Bengal is one of the Indian states where the political power of the Left is still very prominent.
A school for Islamic instruction.
A sultanate formed c. 1400 on the Malay Peninsula. It was conquered by the Portuguese in 1511.
A member of the princely and military castes of Maharashtra
The Indic language of the Marathas

Marxism is a political ideology that is derived from the ideas of Karl Marx. The three primary aspects of Marxism are the dialectical and materialist concept of history, the critique of capitalism, and the advocacy of a proletarian revolution.
A sect of Hinduism
A series of events that restored imperial rule to Japan in 1868.
A 16th to 18th century trade policy advocating state intervention in economic affairs, primarily to maximize exports.
The armed forces of a country.
An economic system geared towards maximizing the extraction of money for the military.
Of or relating to recent times or the present.

Refers to a post-traditional, post-medieval historical period, one marked by the move from feudalism (or agrarianism) toward capitalism, industrialization, secularization, rationalization and the nation-state.

Modernization refers to the transition from the pre-modern or traditional society to a modern one.  Many historian link this transition with the processes of industrialization, urbanization and the spread of education.
The exclusive control of trade in (or supply of) a commodity

The term was first used in English in British India (now India, Bangladesh and Pakistan) and neighbouring countries to refer to the big seasonal winds blowing from the Bay of Bengal and Arabian Sea in the southwest bringing heavy rainfall to the area. The south-west monsoon winds are called 'Nairutya Maarut' in India.
Principles concerning the distinction between right and wrong or good and bad behavior.

The Moghuls were an Islamic imperial power that ruled a large portion of the Indian subcontinent. Their rule began in 1526 with the descendants of the Timurid dynasty. Babur was the first ruler of the Mogul empire. The peak of Mughal rule in India was in 1700 when they controlled most of the Indian sub-continent extending from Bengal in the East to Baluchistan in the West, Kashmir in the North and Kaveri in the South. The rule of the Mugul empire came to an end in the 19th century due to Hindu uprisings and the power of the British Raj. The last Mughal king was Humayun.

Political organization founded in 1906 to protect the rights of Muslims in British India. Its deadlock with the Indian National Congress over the form of government in independent India ultimately led to the partition of British India into India and Pakistan.
A sultanate in Gujarat, India that asserted its independence from the Delhi sultanate in 1403 and remained autonomous until it was incorporated by the Mughals in 1572.
A community outside the four-tier caste system whose members were traditionally boatmen or cultivators
A style of calligraphy used in writing the Perso-Arabic script.

May refer to a community of people who share a common language, culture, ethnicity, descent, and/or history. In this definition, a nation has no physical borders. However, it can also refer to people who share a common territory and government (for example the inhabitants of a sovereign state) irrespective of their ethnic make-up.
The official archives of the governement of the United Kingdom
India's largest library, administered by the government's Department of Culture
The title for the ruler of Hyderabad state.
Riots in Noakhali, Bengal in the months following the Great Calcutta Killings of 1946.
A nonviolent movement in India led by Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi from 1920 to 1922 to resist British rule.
Word denoting the countries of Asia, particular Eastern Asia.

Term that is used in the West to describe many aspects of Eastern cultures. This  term was coined when artists, writers, and designers from the West derived elements of their work from Eastern cultures.
A Muslim empire that lasted from 1299 to 1923. Established in Anatolia, it ruled much of southeastern Europe, western Asia and North Africa at the height of its power.
Oxbridge is the collaboration or the blend between the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge in England.

column1: Oxford Center for South Asian Studies
column4: A research center for South Asian studies housed at the University of Oxford.
A historical research journal founded in 1952.
The official language of Iran, with over 20 million speakers
Sultanate established in Pontianak (part of modern-day Indonesia) in 1771 by explorers from Hadhramaut.

A philosophy of science that holds that the only authentic knowledge is that which is based on sense experience and positive verification. This positivist approach was developed by Auguste Comte in the early 19th century.

Post Modernism refers to the movement in the arts following Modernism. It is usually associated with difference, separation, textuality and skepticism. It is a departure from all that is linked with the modern, such as identity, unity, authority and certainty. Thus it is a rejection of the scientific approach that became prevalent during the Enlightenment.
The ability or capacity to do something or act in a particular way.

Presidency University, Kolkata, formerly Hindu College and Presidency College,is a public state university located in Kolkata, West Bengal.  Established in 1817, it is one of the oldest colleges in India.
That which belongs to someone or something.

Puranik Hinduism is the Hinduism that is depicted in the genre of important Hindu religious texts, Puranas. The Puranas are written in the form of stories that are related by one person to another. They stress on a particular deity and employ an abundance of religious and philosophical concepts.
The sacred text of Islam.

Radicalism is the term that is used to describe the political ideology that involves  supporting or seeking political reforms that include extreme and dramatic changes to the social order. Radicalism could be applied toward the liberals, the right, the left or any other political ideology.
A community that lives mainly in West Bengal, Bangladesh and Assam
See the important exchanges in The Indian Economic and Social History Review
The revival of European art and literature under the influence of classical models in the 14th-16th centuries.
Persianized form of the Khariboli dialect of Urdu
The largest tribal community in India, who live mainly in Eastern India
Philosophy and practice of nonviolent resistance espoused by Gandhi.
The moral code and religious law of Islam.
One of two main branches of Islam, it holds the fourth caliph, Ali, to be the true successor of the prophet Muhammad.

Social History is divided into two branches: the new social history and the old social history. The former concentrates on the politics and diplomacy of events while the latter concentrates on the topics and people without a central theme. This transition from old social history to new social history took place in the 1960s. Moreover, since the 1990s social history is now beginning to focus on cultural history, that is the importance of language, beliefs and assumptions.

The Sri Lankan Civil War was a conflict fought on the island of Sri Lanka. Beginning on 23 July 1983, there was an intermittent insurgency against the government by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (the LTTE, also known as the Tamil Tigers), a separatist militant organisation which fought to create an independent Tamil state called Tamil Eelam in the north and the east of the island. After a 26-year military campaign, the Sri Lankan military defeated the Tamil Tigers in May 2009, bringing the civil war to an end.
One of the premiere colleges of India, located in Delhi.  It was founded in 1881.

Structuralism is an approach to analyze a specific field as a complex system of interrelated parts. Its basis is on the foundation that lies beneath the surface of meaning. It began with the study of linguistics, but then began to be applied to several other fields.

The field that is devoted to the study of history from below, especially realms of social life and culture that are obscured by colonial records. This term could be applied more broadly to other projects that seek to challenge dominant epistemes in the pursuit of more situated forms of knowledge.
The part of Asia south of the Himalayas, consisting of Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan and Sri Lanka
A Muslim ascetic and mystic
Territory held by a sultan, which is a political office that was first created by the Seljuks (1038-1194).
The part of Islamic law based on the Prophet's words and actions accepted as authoritative by Muslim scholars
The Dravidian language of the Tamils spoken mainly in India and Sri Lanka.
A Chinese dynasty (618-907) with its capital at Chang'an
To impose a financial charge or other levy upon a taxpayer, usually an individual, by a state such that failure to pay is punishable by law.
A Communist-led sharecropper movement in Bengal in 1946
A flexible woven material consisting of a network of natural or artificial fibers often referred to as thread or yarn.

The period of British colonial rule over South Asia between 1858 and 1947. The British first established rule over India with the formation of the British East India company.  The region of British rule consisted of British administered areas as well as Indian princely states.
Book written by Bill Ashcroft, Gareth Griffiths, and Helen Tiffin published in 1989.
The transfer of ownership of goods & services from one person or entity to another.
Designation for various nomads who were subjects of the Mongol Empire.
A body of Muslim scholars who are recognized as having specialist knowledge of Islamic sacred law and theology.
A system of medicine practiced in parts of South Asia thought to be derived via medieval Muslim physicians from Byzantine Greece.

An Indic language closely related to Hindi but written in Persian script and having many loanwords from Persian and Arabic. It is the official language of Pakistan, and is also widely used in India and elsewhere
A Shia school of thought that emphasizes the need for conformance to the opinion of authorities of Islamic law
A tradition of Hinduism devoted to the worship of Vishnu as the supreme god and his avatars, Rama and Krishna. It is one of the three major forms of Hindu bhakti, devotion to a single god.
The categorization of Hindu society into four castes: Brahmins, Kshatriyas, Vaishyas and Shudras
The language or dialect spoken by the ordinary people of a country or region

A member of a strictly orthodox Sunni Muslim sect founded by Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab.  Wahhabism advocates a return to the early Islam of the Koran and Sunna, rejecting later innovations.  The sect is still the predominant religious force in Saudi Arabia

The branch of economics that analyzes social welfare measured in terms of economic activities of the individual. It uses microeconomic techniques and determines the allocative efficiency and the income distribution within the society.
The process whereby societies adopt the cultural, economic, or political systems of Europe and North America.
An individual from the country of Yemen in the Arab Peninsula

A movement of patriotic and passionate young Bengalis that strove to get rid of British Rule. This group comprised primarily of of radical Bengali free thinkers emerging from Hindu College, Calcutta in the early 19th century. These individuals were also called Derozians after their teacher at the Hindu College, Henry Louis Vivian Derozio. This movement left a distinct mark in Calcutta society in the 1830s and 1840s.
Water from a well near the Ka'aba in Mecca
The river delta in the South Asia region of Bengal, consisting of Bangladesh and the state of West Bengal, India. It is the world's largest delta, and empties into the Bay of Bengal.
An elite group within the British Malayan community in mid-19th century Malaya.
A major language of the Austronesian family. It is the national language of Indonesia, Malaysia, and Brunei, and it is one of four official languages of Singapore.
Sanskrit is a historical Indo-Aryan language, the primary liturgical language of Hinduism and a literary and scholarly language in Buddhism and Jainism.
Telugu is a Dravidian language predominantly spoken in the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh where it is an official language.
A Malay literary work which covers a period of over 600 years that chronicles the genealogies of the rulers in the Malay Archipelago.
The period of modern history that follows the late Middle Ages of the post-classical era.

One of the longest-ruling dynasties in the history of southern India. The earliest datable references to this Tamil dynasty are in inscriptions from the 3rd century BC left by Asoka, of the Maurya Empire. As one of the Three Crowned Kings, the dynasty continued to govern over varying territory until the 13th century AD.

Kalinga was an early republic in central-eastern India, which comprised most of the modern state of Odisha, as well as the Andhra region of the bordering state of Andhra Pradesh.  The region was the scene of the bloody Kalinga War fought by the Maurya Emperor Ashoka the Great of Magadha c. 265 BCE.
An economic system in which capital assets are privately owned and goods and services are produced for profit in a market economy.
The designation given to an Indian soldier in the service of a European power.
A distinctive Tamil and Malayalam-speaking Muslim people of the states of Tamil Nadu and Kerala in India and Sri Lanka.
A title used by various mercantile castes in South India, especially in Tamil Nadu state.
A caste group found in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu and Kerala.
A Sufi Islamic shrine built over the grave of a revered religious figure, often a Sufi saint or dervish.
A tonal language of the Tai–Kadai language family. It is the official language of Laos, and also spoken in the northeast of Thailand, where it is usually referred to as the Isan language.
The first known Tamil magazine published in 1876, in Penang.
A Tamil language weekly newspaper published in Singapore from 1887 to 1890.
A contiguous transcontinental empire founded by Turkish tribes under Osman Bey in north-western Anatolia in 1299.
A Tamil periodical

A university in Cairo, Egypt. Founded around the year 970 by the Fatimids as a madrasa, or centre of Islamic learning, its students studied the Qur'an and Islamic law in detail, along with logic, grammar, rhetoric, and how to calculate the lunar phases of the moon. It is today a chief centre of Arabic literature and Islamic learning in the world.
A Malay newspaper in Malaysia
An Islamic organization in Indonesia founded in 1923 in London by a group of Muslims who were interested in educational and religious activities led by Haji Muhammad Yunus Zamz.
A belief, creed or political ideology that involves an individual identifying with his or her nation.
Book on late Mughal history by Ghulam Hussain Tabatabai, translated by Haji Mustapha
Arabic word meaning justice, particularly divine justice
Term referring to African and Abyssinian slaves in pre-British India
Hindi word for 'house.'  In colonial India it referred to the residences of British officers.
Honorific title bestowed by Mughals to local rulers
Land given as rent for cultivation
Persian title meaning 'Great King'
Term referring to an aristocrat who owned land and had peasants working under him
1764 battle between the English East India Company and combined forces of Bengal, Awadh and the Mughal Emperor.
Max Weber's theories on sociology
Mosque and tomb near Worli in Mumbai
A sailor or militiaman from the Indian Subcontinent or other countries east of the Cape of Good Hope employed on European ships from the 16th century until the beginning of the 20th century.
Political movement to unite all Muslims under a state
The cuboid building in Mecca, holiest shrine of Islam
A 1920s political protest campaign launched by Muslims in British India to influence the British government and to protect the Ottoman Empire during the aftermath of World War I.
Title of a Sufi master.
Islamic leadership position, particularly with respect to worship
19th century Muslim revivalist movement in India
Dynasty that ruled Persia from 1500 to 1700.
Hindu dynasty that ruled Mysore
The changes brought about by colonial rulers
Financial relationship between a metropole and its colonies
The authority of a state to govern itself.
16th century schism within Western Christianity
Aristocratic title, often referring to full authority

column1: Ideology and Empire in 18th century India
column4: Book written by Robert Travers, published in 2007
Book written by Miles Ogborn, published in 2007
Arabic term referring to the discipline of morality and ethics in Islamic theology
An individual who adheres to Islam
Persian word for a secretary or contractor in British India
Bengali term for the class of gentlefolk that arose during British colonization
An interpreter or guide between Arabic, Turkish, or Persian speaking countries and European embassies or trading companies
Social system of elite land holding in South Asia
Political philosophy that stresses liberty and equality
A famous French secondary school founded in 1563
The idea that all human beings, regardless of ethnicity, belong to a single community with a shared morality
Term associated with post-colonial discourse that refers to the intersection of different cultures.

column1: The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University
column4: School of gradutate studies in international affairs

column1: Monsoon: The Indian Ocean and the future of American power
column4: Book written by journalist Robert Kaplan, published in 2010

column1: His majesty's opponent : Subhas Chandra Bose and India's struggle against empire
column4: Book written by Sugata Bose, published in 2011
Monthly magazine with a focus on literature, politics, and foreign affairs
A cylindrical map projection of the world that has become the standard projection since its creation in the 16th century.
Name of the people and language native to the state of Gujarat in Western India.
Individuals who come from the city of Rome.  Rome ws the capital of the Roman Empire—an empire that reached its peak in the 2nd century extending as far east as Babylonia.
An ethinic group native to Greece, Cyprus, and Anatolia.  Greek civilization extended as far east as the Indus River during the reign of Alexander the Great, a Greek king during the 4th century BCE.
An ethnic group centered around the Malay peninsula.
Politicaly motivated sabotage carried out on the Internet against a nation or group of people
The branch of the United States military dedicated to naval warfare.
The branch of the Chinese military dedicated to naval warfare.
The branch of the Indian military dedicated to naval warfare.

column1: Where China meets India : Burma and the new crossroads of Asia
column4: Book written by Thant Myint-U, published in 2011
A narrow strip of land with sea on either side that connects two larger land masses
A place of worship in Islam
Center of higher learning in Bihar, India from the 5th to 12th centuries AD
A conflict between Iraq and Kuwait during August 1990 in which resulted in the seven month long Iraqi occupation of Kuwait.
The destruction of the physical barrier separating East and West Germany in November, 1989.
A television broadcaster headquartered in Qatar.
International organization of 20 member states that aims to promote greater economic cooperation among nations that border the Indian Ocean.
An economic campaign launched by the Communist Party of China from 1958 to 1961.  A major component of the campaign was agricultural collectivization.
A 1960s campaign by the Communist Party of China with the aim of eradicating capitalist structures and enforcing communist and Maoist doctrine.
A Chinese imperial dynasty that lasted from the 7th to 10th centuries AD.
Book written by Amitav Ghosh, published in 2008.
Term referrs to the trading of the drug opium which became more regular in 17th century China.
The military arm of the Community Party of China.
Term originally referring to countries that were not aligned with NATO or the Communist Bloc.  The term has since evolved to refer to poorer countries that struggle to maintain economic development.
Refers to the demarcation line used by the governments of China and Taiwan for their claim in the South China Sea.
A military conflict between the Kachin ethnic group and the Burmese army in 2011
A political philosophy that aims to strengthen India's political influence in South Asia.
Generic term for militant communist group operating in China
The control of the executive branch of the United States government by Barack Obama when he assumed the office of the presidency in January 2009.
The strategy of the Obama administration to refocus and bolster the United State's foreign policy efforts in Asia.
The political theory of the Chinese Communist leader Mao Zedong.

column2: United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea
column4: International agreement that defines the rights and responsibilities of nations in their use of the world's oceans.
A powerful Malay empire that lasted from the 7th to the 14th centuries AD.
War between France and the Kingdom of Prussia that lasted from 1870 to 1871.

column1: A hundred horizons: the Indian Ocean in the age of global empire
column4: Book written by Sugata Bose, published in 2006

column1: Return of a king: the battle for Afghanistan, 1839-42
column4: Book written by William Dalrymple, publised in 2013.  The book examins the first Anglo-Afghan War.
War fought by the British East India Company from 1839-1842 in an effort to control Afghanistan.
Dari is the dialect of Persian spoken in Afghanistan where, along with Pashto, it is one of the two official languages.
A group based in southern Russia noted for their horsemanship and military skill.  During the reign of the czars the Cossacks were often charged with protecting Russia's frontiers.
The national library of the United Kingdom.
Term referring to the rivalry between Great Britain and Russia for supremacy in Central Asia.
War between Russia and the alliance of Britain, France, and the Ottoman Empire fought over the rights of Christians in the Holy Land.
Bi-annual periodical founded in 1844 by Sir John William Kaye and Reverend Alexander Duff.
A Sunni Muslim dynasty that ruled over Central Asia from 1370 to 1507.
An Islamic fundamentalist movement in Afghanistan founded in 1994.
The ruling dynasty of Afghanistan founded by Dost Mohammad Khan after the Durrani dynasty.  The Barakzai played major roles in the politics of Afghanistan until their dissolution in 1973.
Arabic term referring to those Mulims who struggle for the sake of Islam.  The term has evolved to denote militant Islamic groups specifically.

column1: The last Mughal: the fall of a dynastyL Delhi, 1857
column4: Book written by William Dalrymple, published in 2007.

column1: White Mughals: love and betrayal in the eighteenth-century India
column4: Book written by William Dalrymple, published in 2003.
An Afghan tribe that is ethinically Pashtun.

column1: State and tribe in nineteenth-century Afghanistan: the reign of Amir Dost Muhammad Khan (1826-1863)
column4: Book written by Christine Noelle, published in 1997.
An empire of the Indian subcontinent founded in 1799 by Ranjit Singh.
A genre of epic or heroic poetry in the literatures of India, Pakistan, and Afghanistan.
A Pashtun tribal confederacy
A subgroup of the Popalzai tribe credited with founding the Durrani dynasty.

column2: Journal of the International African Institute
column4: Academic journal devoted to the study of African cultures and societies.
The Indian community of East Africa.  The Indian diaspora began to grow in the 19th century with the arrival of Indian indentured laborers from British India sent to build the Kenyan railroad system.
A follower of Hinduism.
The major religious tradition of the Indian subcontinent.  Hinduism is comprised of multiple devotional and philosophical schools.
A follower of Sikhism.
A monotheistic religion founded in Northern India in the 15th century.
Name referring to individuals from the Punjab region in Northern India.
Railway system connecting Uganda and Kenya, built by the British starting in 1901.
The largest ethnic group in Kenya, they are members of the Bantu people of East Africa.
Prominent mosque in Nairobi, Kenya built between 1902 and 1906.
French term referring to the lower middle class of a society.
Kenya attained independence from Great Britain in 1963.
Founded in 1942, the Kenya African Union was an African nationalist organization that demanded access to white-owned land.
A political party founded in the early 20th century that advocated for the creation of Muslim-majority nation, Pakistan.
The 48th imam of the Nizari Ismaili community.
An organization of workers in a particular trade, formed to protect and further their rights and interests.
An Islamic reform movement founded in British India in the 19th century.
The British colony in present-day Kenya.  Kenya was a British colony from 1920 to 1963.
The form of nationalism that arose mainly in Asia and Africa during the period of decolonization in the 20th century.
Term referring to an individual's loyalty to the established government.
The idea that an individual's identity with a global community is more significant than his identity with a particular nation.
The separation of individuals into racial groups in daily life.
A branch of Shia Islam.
Organization formed in 1943 in Nairobi to with aim of giving Muslims in Kenya a greater political voice.
Research institute that studies the history of labor.

column1: The Bengal borderland : beyond state and nation in South Asia
column4: Book written by Willem Van Schendel, published in 2005.

column1: Global blue : Indigo and espionage in colonial Bengal
column4: Book written by Willem Van Schendel and Pierre-Paul Darrac, published in 2006.

column1: The Bangladesh reader : history, culture, politics
column4: Book written by Willem Van Schendel and Meghana Guhathakurata, published in 2013.
A cooperative project among Asian and European countries that aims to improve the highway infrastructure of Asia.
Term referring to the network of Chinese military facilities that stretches from the Chinese mainland across the Indian Ocean to the Port of Sudan.
Project that aims to build a freight railway network across Europe and Asia.
The 1971 war of independence that led to the establishment of the nation of Bangladesh.
A species of plant that is cultivated for its fiber.
An Indo-Aryan language spoken by the people of Chittagong in Bangladesh.
A dialect of Burmese spoken in western Burma, Bangladesh, and parts of India.
The oldest branch of Buddhism, practiced predominantly in South Asia.
The largest branch of Christianity, its adherents acknowledge the Pope as the head of the Church.
Term referring to the attempt to break down and categorize world history into discrete blocks.
An Asian religion and philosophy founded by Siddartha Gautama (i.e. the Buddha) in northeast India in the 5th century BCE.
Term referring to the process by which a geographic location becomes a focal point for an group's narrative and identity.
A South Asian ethinic group who practice Islam and speak Rohingya—a language closely related to Bengali and Chittagonian.
Arabic word meaning "immigrant."  In the context of South Asia, the word typically refers to those people who relocated to Pakistan after its partition from India inn 1947.
An ancient kingdom that ruled much of the eastern half of the Indian subcontinent.
A kingdom in ancient Bengal, located at the mouth of the Brahmaputra river.

column4: Book written by Nile Green, published in 2011.

column4: Book written by Nile Green, published in 2009.

column4: Book written by Christopher Bayly, published in 2004.
Book written by Olivier Roy, published in 2004.

column1: Awash in a sea of faith
column4: Book written by Jon Butler, published in 1990.
German sociological term for "disenchantment," referring to devaluation of mysticism in modern society.
Term referring to the religious behavior patterns of individuals and groups.
A branch of Islam often charactizered as more mystical and esoteric than the Sunni or Shia branches, it reached its peak in the 13th century.

column1: American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions
column4: An American Christian missionary organization founded in 1810.
Term employed by E.P. Thompson that refers to an economy based on fairness and justice.
Islamic theological term referring to the concept of "intercession."
Term referring to the death anniversary and commemoration rituals of a Sufi saint.
A monotheisitic pre-Islamic religion that flourished in Persia in the 6th century BCE.
A 19th century movement among Bengali Muslims that aimed to counter British and Hindu influences on Muslims.
Term referring to Sufi ascetics who were wandering teachers living on alms.
Book written by E.P. Thompson, published in 1991.
The comparison of different societies that existed during the same time period.
19th century religious movement that began in New York.  Spiritualism postulated the belief that the spirits of the dead communicate with the living.
A school located in Mumbai founded in 1874.
Public procession and rituals in Shia Islam that mark the anniversary of the Battle of Karbala in which Hussein ibn Ali, the grandson of the Prophet, was killed.
Term from Islamic law referring to the tax levied on an Islamic state's non-Muslim citizens.
Arabic term meaning "obstacle," referring to the barrier between the spiritual and physical worlds.
A member of the Zoroastrian communities of South Asia.
Arabic term meaning "to follow," referring to the following of religious laws as they are interpreted by religious leaders.
An infantry regiment of the Bengal Army and later of the raj-period Indian Army. It was active from 1803 to 1922.
A hereditary seat and the nominal ruler of the Malaysian state of Johor.
An armed force formed by Indian nationalists in 1942 in Southeast Asia during World War II.
The last imperial dynasty of China, ruling from 1644 to 1912 with a brief, abortive restoration in 1917.
Attack on the German port of Tsingtao (Qingdao) in China during World War I by Japan and the United Kingdom.

Treaty designed to solve many of the issues that had arisen due to the British occupation of Dutch properties during the Napoleonic Wars, as well as issues regarding the rights to trade that existed for hundreds of years in the Spice Islands between the two nations.

A set of demands made during the First World War by Japan under Prime Minister Okuma Shigenobu sent to the government of the Republic of China on January 18, 1915. The demands would greatly extend Japanese control of Manchuria and of the Chinese economy.

column2: 1915 Sepoy Mutiny; Mutiny of 5th Native Light Infantry
column4: A mutiny involving up to half of 850 sepoys (Indian soldiers) against the British in Singapore during the First World War.
People inhabiting the Hadhramaut region in Yemen and their descendants in diaspora communities around the world. They speak Hadhrami Arabic.

Name of a Japanese steamship that sailed from Punjab to Vancouver in 1914, carrying 376 passengers from India. Only 20 of the passengers were admitted to Canada, the other 356 passengers were not allowed to land and the ship was forced to return to India.

The Ghadar Party was an organization founded by Punjabi Indians in the United States and Canada with the aim to liberate India from British rule. Key members included lala Har Dayal, Sohan Singh Bhakna, Kartar Singh Sarabha, and Rashbehari Bose.
Term meaning 'the gateway to the guru"; the place of worship for Sikhs.

Term referring to philosophies maintaining that a knowledge of God may be achieved through spiritual ecstasy, direct intuition, or special individual relations.  Particularly refers to the movement founded in 1875 as the Theosophical Society by Helena Blavatsky and Henry Steel Olcott (1832–1907).
A wave of mass political and social unrest that spread throughout the Russian Empire in 1905.
Armed military conflict between the people of the Philippines and Spanish colonial authorities that lasted from 1896 to 1898.
Violent anti-foreign and anti-Christian movement which took place in China between 1899 and 1901.
The Battle of Port Arthur of 8–9 February, 1904 marked the commencement of the Russo-Japanese War.

A United States federal law passed on June 15, 1917, intended to prohibit interference with military operations or recruitment, to prevent insubordination in the military, and to prevent the support of U.S. enemies during wartime.

1918 act of the United States Congress that extended the Espionage Act of 1917 to cover a broader range of offenses, notably speech and the expression of opinion that cast the government or the war effort in a negative light or interfered with the sale of government bonds.
International communist organization initiated in Moscow during March 1919
1932 American film directed by Josef von Sternberg.
Sarekat Islam, formerly Sarekat Dagang Islam, was a Javanese batik traders cooperative in Indonesia.
Global militant Islamist and takfiri organization founded by Osama bin Laden in Peshawar, Pakistan
Famous Mughal Unani medical text.
Late Mughal period medical text.
Term referring to the concept of monotheism in Islam.
The capture and sacking of Baghdad, the capital of the Abbasid Caliphate, by Ilkhanate Mongol forces and allied troops in 1258 CE.
A particular type of charter or edict issued by a Pope of the Catholic Church.

A papal bull issued by Pope Alexander VI on 4 May 1493, which granted to Spain (the Crowns of Castile and Aragon) all lands to the "west and south" of a pole-to-pole line 100 leagues west and south of any of the islands of the Azores or the Cape Verde islands.

A religious movement among fundamentalist Islamic believers, with an aspiration to return to the earliest fundamental Islamic sources of the Quran and Hadith, with inspiration from the teachings of medieval theologian Ibn Taymiyyah and early jurist Ahmad ibn Hanbal.
The first of five unrelated dynasties to rule India's Delhi Sultanate from 1206 to 1290.
